title: Band (Peru), 100 BC–800 AD
medium:
Medium: cotton and wool
Technique: tapestry weave; 3 sections: a) slit tapestry, b) slit tapestry with non-horizontal wefts and weft wrapping, and  c) slit tapestry, use of non-horizontal wefts
Label: cotton and wool slit tapestry with some weft wrapping
description: Fragment of a tapestry-woven band with varied zigzag stripe and diamond patterns, in red, yellow, green, black and tan.
gallery_text: The fine weaving of this narrow band, with eccentric wefts that follow the diagonals of the design, marks it as a special item. Among the brilliantly dyed blue, yellow and red yarns, a fuzzy, coffee-colored yarn stands out.  The fiber source may be an extremely fine camelid, such as the wild guanaco, or rabbit hair, or viscacha-- the precious chinchilla whose soft, silky hair was so prized by the Andean people. These fibers, identifiable by their texture and color, signal luxury and possibly religious meaning.  The cloudlike, arched forms are followed by the zigzag design, a universal representation of lightning. Among the Inca, lightning represented a major god known as Llalapa, lending an aura of mystical or shamanistic engagement to the workings of the universe that may have been thought come into play through the wearing of this band.

tombstone.epitaph:
Band (Peru), 100 BC–800 AD. Medium: cotton and wool
Technique: tapestry weave; 3 sections: a) slit tapestry, b) slit tapestry with non-horizontal wefts and weft wrapping, and  c) slit tapestry, use of non-horizontal wefts
